Why I have a website

Last updated on November 21, 2022
This is for People who have never owned a personal website, who have a vague understanding of why anybody would want to, and who are not sure how they'd ever get started. For example, my friend Nienke. Hi Nienke!

Welcome to my home on the Internet. This website was hand-built by me, and I‚Äôm the only one publishing things on it. It contains facts about me and the work I do, but also working notes on some of my ideas, as well as short and longer diary entries. This is an example of a personal website.

You should make a personal website

Having my own website has many benefits, some you might not have thought of.

Where people can find you

If I need to find a person, I google them. I don‚Äôt use social media, and I usually don‚Äôt enjoy having to log on to find who I‚Äôm looking for. When you own your own website, people don‚Äôt need to log back on to that no-longer-popular platform to find you.

Owning your stuff

Showing your personality

My place on the web

When people Google me, the first thing they will see is a link to this website. On here, those interested can learn more about my work, and other things that are important to me.

The anatomy of the personal website

A personal website is a web page or a cluster thereof showcasing anything the owner cares to share: examples of work, essays in blog form, snapshots, discovered links, whatever you can think of. It is the website version of the oft-seen Twitter bio ‚Äúviews are my own‚Äù.

Many people choose to segregate the personal information they share on a personal website. Some limit it to their work, others to their goings-on at home. Some use a single domain to share everything, like me.

Personal websites as an invitation

That's all for now. Eager to see me add some more to this page? Feel free to nudge me.

Zinzy Waleson Geene (she/ they) is a researcher, designer, and queer facilitator from Amsterdam. She's interested in humanities and behavioral sciences, yoga practice, and amateur cooking. She engages in mellow cultural and critical analysis, linking and tinkering on her personal website, zinzy.website .
